747.question: How do the backoff strategies work?
747.response: {'Answer': 'Backoff strategies are used when a word recognition system fails to recognize a word. The system will then use a different model to recognize the word. These models include a neutral, pass-through, and background model. The best performing backoff strategy is the background model, which uses a large corpus of data to recognize words. This strategy is shown to have the lowest sensitivity value, as well as having the lowest Word Error Rate (WER) on a smaller, domain-specific dataset (See figure 2). The background model is robust against adversarial attacks and is able to recover over 76% of the original accuracy under the ‘all’ setting for all four model classes (See table 3).'}
747.answer: In pass-through, the recognizer passes on the possibly misspelled word, backoff to neutral word backs off to a word with similar distribution across classes and backoff to background model backs off to a more generic word recognition model trained with larger and less specialized corpus.

748.question: How do the backoff strategies work?
748.response: {'Answer': 'Backoff strategies are used to handle out-of-vocabulary (OOV) words during word recognition. These strategies aim to minimize errors when the model encounters words it hasn’t seen before. The table shows the word error rates (WER) of ScRNN, a word recognition model, with various backoff strategies.  Pass-through, Neutral, and Background are the three strategies employed.  The table also includes ATD (a conventional spelling corrector) and a model trained only on the background corpus. These strategies are effective for dealing with OOV words, especially when training on limited data, and can contribute to more robust word recognition.'}
748.answer: Pass-through passes the possibly misspelled word as is, backoff to neutral word backs off to a word with similar distribution across classes and backoff to background model backs off to a more generic word recognition model trained with larger and less specialized corpus.

749.question: How do the backoff strategies work?
749.response: {'Answer': 'Backoff strategies are used in word recognition systems to improve accuracy and robustness. They work by combining a foreground model, trained on a smaller, domain-specific dataset, with a background model, trained on a larger, more general dataset. The foreground model is used to recognize words that are in the specific domain, while the background model is used to recognize words that are not in the domain. In the case of unknown words, the system can "back off" to the background model. The authors of the paper experiment with three backoff strategies, Pass-Through, Neutral, and Background. The results of their experiments show that the Background backoff strategy is the most effective, achieving the lowest Word Error Rate (WER).'}
749.answer: Backoff to "a" when an UNK-predicted word is encountered, backoff to a more generic word recognition model when the model predicts UNK
